title: Modified Glasgow Prognostic Score (mGPS) for Cancer Outcomes
description: Provides improved cancer prognosis over the original Glasgow Prognostic Score, based on serum biomarkers (CRP and albumin) reflecting systemic inflammation and nutritional status

result.name: mgps_score
result.description: Modified Glasgow Prognostic Score (0-2 points) indicating cancer prognosis

ranges.interpretation: Normal inflammatory markers. CRP ≤10 mg/L (regardless of albumin level).
Elevated inflammation with adequate nutrition. CRP >10 mg/L and albumin ≥35 g/L.
Elevated inflammation with poor nutrition. CRP >10 mg/L and albumin <35 g/L.

references: Proctor MJ, Morrison DS, Talwar D, Balmer SM, O'Reilly DS, Foulis AK, Horgan PG, McMillan DC. An inflammation-based prognostic score (mGPS) predicts cancer survival independent of tumour site: a Glasgow Inflammation Outcome Study. Br J Cancer. 2011 Aug 23;105(5):726-34. doi: 10.1038/bjc.2011.292.
McMillan DC. The systemic inflammation-based Glasgow Prognostic Score: a decade of experience in patients with cancer. Cancer Treat Rev. 2013 Aug;39(5):534-40. doi: 10.1016/j.ctrv.2012.08.003.

Forrest LM, McMillan DC, McArdle CS, Angerson WJ, Dunlop DJ. Evaluation of cumulative prognostic scores based on the systemic inflammatory response in patients with inoperable non-small-cell lung cancer. Br J Cancer. 2003 Aug 4;89(3):477-81. doi: 10.1038/sj.bjc.6601242.
formula: Score determined by CRP and albumin levels. Score 0: CRP ≤10 mg/L (any albumin). Score 1: CRP >10 mg/L and albumin ≥35 g/L. Score 2: CRP >10 mg/L and albumin <35 g/L.
notes: Modified version weighs inflammatory component (CRP) more heavily than original GPS
Low albumin alone (without elevated CRP) scores 0 points in mGPS vs 1 point in original GPS
Validated across multiple cancer types including gastric, renal, lung, pancreatic, and colorectal cancers
Reflects both systemic inflammatory response and nutritional status
Higher scores associated with worse overall survival, disease-specific survival, and disease-free survival
Should be interpreted in context of cancer stage, treatment status, and other prognostic factors
Not a standalone diagnostic or treatment decision tool
Survival outcomes vary significantly based on patient selection and cancer type
Can provide prognostic information beyond traditional TNM staging
